items.title: Comfortable away win for Burton Albion against Boreham Wood
items.summary: Kain Adom is instrumental on his Burton Albion debut as the Brewers get past National League side Boreham Wood in the third round of the FA Cup.

items.title: 'My best foot's my head!' - Dawson proud after shock Macclesfield win
items.summary: Macclesfield captain Paul Dawson says "it means the world" after his side secured a shock win against Premier League side Crystal Palace, as the non-league team knocked out the defending champions with a 2-1 win.

items.title: Kavanaugh Stop
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Cardiff on brink of Challenge Cup knockout stages
items.summary: Cardiff take a huge step to guarantee their Challenge Cup knockout place with a hard-fought bonus-point home win against Racing 92.

items.title: Roefs the hero as Sunderland beat Everton on penalties
items.summary: Robin Roefs saves three out of three penalties as Sunderland knocked out Everton in the third round of the FA Cup.

items.title: UpCodes (YC S17) is hiring PMs, SWEs to automate construction compliance
items.summary: Comments

items.title: AI is a business model stress test
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Microsoft May Have Created the Slowest Windows in 25 Years with Windows 11
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Undisciplined Exeter throw away chance of Stade win
items.summary: Undisciplined Exeter throw away a 22-point lead to lose at Stade Francais in the European Challenge Cup.

items.title: Time-wasting by goalkeepers can harm WSL 'attractiveness'
items.summary: Arsenal manager Renee Slegers says time-wasting by goalkeepers in the Women's Super League can harm the "attractiveness" of the game.

items.title: Bristol beat Bulls in astonishing 16-try contest
items.summary: Bristol Bears qualify for the Champions Cup knockout stage by winning an astonishing 16-try contest with the Bulls in Pretoria.

items.title: 'Power, speed and ability' - why Spurs are excited by Gaupset
items.summary: BBC Sport looks at Tottenham's signing of exciting 20-year-old midfielder Signe Gaupset from Norwegian top-flight side Brann.

items.title: Leicester ease past Cheltenham with comfortable win
items.summary: Patson Daka scores his first FA Cup goal to help Championship side Leicester City ease past League Two Cheltenham Town and into the fourth round.

items.title: Strand Larsen scores hat-trick as Wolves thrash Shrewsbury
items.summary: Striker Jorgen Strand Larsen's hat-trick ends his Wolves goal drought as he fires them past League Two Shrewsbury into the FA Cup fourth round.

items.title: Open Chaos: A self-evolving open-source project
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Engadget Podcast: Best of CES 2026 and a chat with Pebble's founder

Also, Cherlynn chats with Pebble founder Eric Migicovsky about his Pebble smartwatch revival, as well as an intriguing new AI ring thatâ€™â€¦

items.title: The robots we saw at CES 2026: The lovable, the creepy and the utterly confusing
items.summary: CES always has its share of attention-grabbing robots. But this year in particular seemed to be a landmark year for robotics. The advancement in AI technology has not only given robots better â€œbrains,â€ itâ€™s enabled new levels of autonomy and given rise to an ambitious, if sometimes questionable, viâ€¦

items.summary: Roborock is launching a limited-time promotion on its latest F25 series floor cleaners, offering meaningful discounts on both the impressive flagship F25 Ultra and the more affordable F25 GT. Starting today, these deals make Roborockâ€™s newest wet and dry cleaning technology affordable for everyone.â€¦

items.title: NASA makes final preparations for its first crewed moon mission in over 50 years
items.summary: Back in 2024, NASA announced that the Artemis 2 mission was going to be pushed back to April 2026. Now, the agency says it could launch as early as February, with the first flight opportunity being on February 6. NASA is currently making the final preparations for the mission and will soon roll outâ€¦

items.title: Dominant Sabalenka reaches Brisbane final
items.summary: World number one Aryna Sabalenka reaches the final of the Brisbane International for the third year in a row with victory over Karolina Muchova.

items.title: SpaceX gets FCC permission to launch another 7,500 Starlink satellites
items.summary: Including previous approvals, Starlink can now deploy 15,000 Gen2 satellites.
items.body: SpaceX today received US permission to launch another 7,500 second-generation Starlink satellites, bringing its total authorization to 15,000 Gen2 satellites including those previously approved. "Under this grant, SpaceX is authorized to construct, deploy, and operate an additional 7,500 Gen2 Starlink satellites, bringing the total to 15,000 satellites worldwide," the Federal Communications Commission announced today. "This expansion will enable SpaceX to deliver high-speed, low-latency Internet service globally, including enhanced mobile and supplemental coverage from space." The FCC gave SpaceX permission for the first set of 7,500 satellites in December 2022 . The agency deferred action on the rest of the second-generation constellation at the time and limited the first batch to certain altitudes, saying it needed to "address concerns about orbital debris and space safety" before approving the full bunch. items.title: ESA considers righting the wrongs of Ariane 6 by turning it into a Franken-rocket
items.summary: ArianeGroup is still trying to catch up to where the bleeding edge of the launch industry was 15 years ago.
items.body: It took a while, but a consensus has emerged in Europe that the continent's space industry needs to develop reusable rockets. How to do it and how much to spend on it remain unresolved questions. Much of the discourse around reusable rockets in Europe has focused on developing a brand new rocket that might eventually replace the Ariane 6, which debuted less than two years ago but still uses the use it and lose it model embraced by the launch industry for most of the Space Age. The European Space Agency (ESA) is offering money to emerging rocket companies in Europe to prove their small satellite launchers can do the job. ESA is also making money available to incentivize rocket upgrades to haul heavier cargo into orbit. ESA, the European Commission, and national governments are funding rocket hoppers to demonstrate vertical takeoff and vertical landing technologies. While there is significant money behind these efforts, the projects are not unified, and progress has been slow. Read full article Comments

items.title: Measles continues raging in South Carolina; 99 new cases since Tuesday
items.summary: With so many exposures sites, officials can't figure out where people were infected.
items.body: A measles outbreak in South Carolina that began in October continues to rage, with the state health department reporting Friday that nearly 100 new cases have been identified just in the last three days. In a regularly scheduled update this afternoon, the health department said 99 cases were identified since Tuesday, bringing the outbreak total to 310 cases . There are currently 200 people in quarantine and nine in isolation. However, the outbreak is expanding so quickly and with so many exposure sites that health officials are struggling to trace cases and identify people at risk. "An increasing number of public exposure sites are being identified with likely hundreds more people exposed who are not aware they should be in quarantine if they are not immune to measles," Dr. Linda Bell, state epidemiologist and the health department's incident commander for the measles outbreak, said in the announcement. "Previous measles transmission studies have shown that one measles case can result in up to 20 new infections among unvaccinated contacts." Read full article Comments

items.title: Google: Donâ€™t make â€œbite-sizedâ€ content for LLMs if you care about search rank
items.summary: Google says creating for people rather than robots is the best long-term strategy.
items.body: Search engine optimization, or SEO, is a big business. While some SEO practices are useful, much of the day-to-day SEO wisdom you see online amounts to superstition. An increasingly popular approach geared toward LLMs called "content chunking" may fall into that category. In the latest installment of Google's Search Off the Record podcast , John Mueller and Danny Sullivan say that breaking content down into bite-sized chunks for LLMs like Gemini is a bad idea. You've probably seen websites engaging in content chunking and scratched your head, and for good reasonâ€”this content isn't made for you. The idea is that if you split information into smaller paragraphs and sections, it is more likely to be ingested and cited by generative AI bots like Gemini. So you end up with short paragraphs, sometimes with just one or two sentences, and lots of subheds formatted like questions one might ask a chatbot. According to Sullivan, this is a misconception, and Google doesn't use such signals to improve ranking. "One of the things I keep seeing over and over in some of the advice and guidance and people are trying to figure out what do we do with the LLMs or whatever, is that turn your content iâ€¦

items.title: Cloudflare defies Italyâ€™s Piracy Shield, wonâ€™t block websites on 1.1.1.1 DNS
items.summary: Italy fines Cloudflare 14M euros for not blocking pirate sites on 1.1.1.1 DNS service.
items.body: Italy fined Cloudflare 14.2 million euros for refusing to block access to pirate sites on its 1.1.1.1 DNS service, the country's communications regulatory agency, AGCOM, announced yesterday. Cloudflare said it will fight the penalty and threatened to remove all of its servers from Italian cities. AGCOM issued the fine under Italy's controversial Piracy Shield law, saying that Cloudflare was required to disable DNS resolution of domain names and routing of traffic to IP addresses reported by copyright holders. The law provides for fines up to 2 percent of a company's annual turnover, and the agency said it applied a fine equal to 1 percent. The fine relates to a blocking order issued to Cloudflare in February 2025. Cloudflare argued that installing a filter applying to the roughly 200 billion daily requests to its DNS system would significantly increase latency and negatively affect DNS resolution for sites that aren't subject to the dispute over piracy. Read full article Comments

items.title: US Black Hawk helicopter trespasses on private Montana ranch to grab elk antlers
items.summary: Crazy, but that's how it goes.
items.body: Collecting fallen (or "shed") elk antlers is a popular pastime in elk-heavy places like Montana, but it's usually a pretty low-tech, on-the-ground affair. That's why last year's story about a US Black Hawk helicopter descending from the skies to harvest shed elk antlers on a ranch was such an odd one. Was it really possible that US military personnel were using multimillion-dollar government aircraft to land on private property in the Crazy Mountainsâ€”yes, that's their actual nameâ€”just to grab some antlers valued at a few hundred bucks? Antler hunt In May 2025, Montana rancher Linda McMullen received a call from a neighbor. "He said, 'Linda, thereâ€™s a green Army helicopter landed on your place, picking up elk antlers,â€™â€ McMullen told The New York Times last year . â€œI said, â€˜Are you joking?â€™ He said, â€˜Iâ€™m looking at them with binoculars.â€™â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: These 60,000-year-old poison arrows are oldest yet found
items.summary: Hunter-gatherers probably derived the poison from the milky bulb extract of a Boophone disticha plant.
items.body: Poisoned arrows or darts have long been used by cultures all over the world for hunting or warfare. For example, there are recipes for poisoning projective weapons, and deploying them in battle, in Greek and Roman historical documents, as well as references in Greek mythology and Homer's Iliad and Odyssey . Chinese warriors over the ages did the same, as did the Gauls and Scythians, and some Native American populations. Archaeologists have now found traces of a plant-based poison on several 60,000-year-old quartz Stone Age arrowheads found in South Africa, according to a new paper published in the journal Science Advances. That would make this the oldest direct evidence of using poisons on projectilesâ€”a cognitively complex hunting strategyâ€”and pushes the timeline for using poison arrows back into the Pleistocene. The poisons commonly used could be derived from plants or animals (frogs, beetles, venomous lizards). Plant-based examples include curare, a muscle relaxant that paralyzes the victim's respiratory system, causing death by asphyxiation. Oleander, milkweeds, or inee (onaye) contain cardiac glucosides. In Southeast Asia, the sap or juice of seeds from the ancar tree is smearâ€¦

Several years after that, she used the listings website to find the rent-controlled apartment where she still lives today. When she wanted to buy property, she scrolled through Craigslist and found a parcel of land in the Mojave Desert. She built a dwelling on it (never mind that sheâ€™d later discover it was unpermitted) and furnished it entirely with finds from Craigslistâ€™s free section, right down to the laminate flooring, which had previously been used by a production company. â€œThereâ€™s so many elements of my life that are suffused with Craigslist,â€ says Koester, 42, whose Instagram account is dedicated, at least in part, to cataloging screenshots of what she has dubbed â€œharrowing imagesâ€ from the siteâ€™s free section; on the day we speak, sheâ€™s wearing a cashmere sweater that cost her nothing, besides the faith it took to respond to an ad with no pictures. â€œIâ€™m ride or die.â€ Koester is one of untold numbers of Craigslist aficionados, many of them in their thirties and forties, who not only still use the old-school classifieâ€¦

items.title: General Motors writes down $6 billion as domestic EV sales plans change
items.summary: Canceled contracts and scaled-back product plans turn out to be costly.
items.body: American automakers who got overenthusiastic about electric vehicles continue to pay the priceâ€”literally. Yesterday, General Motors told investors that building and selling fewer EVs will cost the company $6 billion. Still, things could be worseâ€”last month, rival Ford said it would write down $19.5 billion as a result of its failed EV bet. GM is not actually abandoning its EV portfolio, even as it reduces shifts at some plants and repurposes othersâ€”like the one in Orion, Michiganâ€”into assembling combustion-powered pickups and SUVs instead of EVs. The electric crossovers, SUVs, and pickups from Cadillac, Chevrolet, and GMC will remain on sale, with the rebatteried Chevy Bolt joining their ranks this year. But GM says it expects to sell many fewer EVs than once planned. For one thing, the US government abolished the clean vehicle tax credit, which cut the price of an American-made EV by up to $7,500. That government has also told automakers it no longer cares if they sell plenty of inefficient vehicles. Add to that the hostility from car dealers by having to sell EVs in the first place, and one can see why GM has decided to retreat, even if we might not sympathize. Read full articleâ€¦

The boxy model strongly resembles the company's Soul (Kia did make an electric Soul at one point) and has very similar dimensions, though it's slightly shorter in height and length. It's not exactly a range monster and will charge a biâ€¦

items.title: 'Knitted' satellite launching to monitor Earth's surface with radar
items.summary: A standard industrial knitting machine has been modified to produce fabrics from tungsten wire coated in gold, which are used to form the dish on the CarbSAR satellite

items.title: Lego is trying to make tech invisible with Smart Play
items.summary: Probably my favorite thing about the Lego Smart Play system unveiled this week at CES is that it was designed for kids, first and foremost. In the past 10 years or so, Lego has increasingly courted an older audience with more expensive and elaborate sets. But when it was time to bring more advancedâ€¦

items.title: Spotify is no longer running ads for ICE
items.summary: There are no recruitment ads for Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) running on Spotify at the moment, the streaming service has told Variety. A spokesperson has confirmed the news after an ICE agent fatally shot Renee Good in Minneapolis, but they also clarified that the ads stopped running â€¦

items.title: NASA orders â€œcontrolled medical evacuationâ€ from the International Space Station
items.summary: "The crew is highly trained, and they came to the aid of their colleague right away."
items.body: NASA officials said Thursday they have decided to bring home four of the seven crew members on the International Space Station after one of them experienced a "medical situation" earlier this week. The space agency has said little about the incident, and officials have not identified which crew member suffered the medical issue. James "JD" Polk, NASA's chief health and medical officer, told reporters Thursday the crew member is "absolutely stable" but that the agency is "erring on the side of caution" with the decision to return the astronaut to Earth. The ailing astronaut is part of the Crew-11 mission, which launched to the station August 1 and was slated to come back to Earth around February 20. Instead, the Crew-11 astronauts will depart the International Space Station (ISS) in the coming days and head for reentry and a parachute-assisted splashdown in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California. Read full article Comments

items.title: Michigan man learns the hard way that â€œcatch a cheaterâ€ spyware apps arenâ€™t legal
items.summary: Spying doesn't become legal just because "cheaters" are the targets.
items.body: In 2002, Bryan Fleming helped to create pcTattletale, software for monitoring phone and computer usage. Fleming's tool would record everything done on the target device, and the videos would be uploaded to a server where they could be viewed by the pcTattletale subscriber. This might sound creepy, but it can also be legal when used by a parent monitoring their child or an employee monitoring their workers. These are exactly the use cases that were once outlined on pcTattletale's website, where the software was said to have "helped tens of thousands of parents stop their daughters from meeting up with pedophiles." Businesses can "track productivity, theft, lost hours, and more." Even "police departments use it for investigating." But this week, nearly 25 years after launching pcTattletale, Fleming pled guilty in federal court to having knowingly built and marketed software to spy on other adults without their consent. In other words, pcTattletale was often used to spy on romantic partners without their knowledgeâ€”and Fleming helped people do it. Read full article Comments

items.title: High RAM prices mean record-setting profits for Samsung and other memory makers
items.summary: SK Hynix and Micron are also riding high on the AI industry's demand for RAM.
items.body: Supply shortages and big price increases for RAM and storage have been a major drag for enthusiasts and PC builders in recent months. And while we haven't yet seen large, widespread price increases for memory-dependent products like pre-built laptop PCs, smartphones, and graphics cards, most companies expect that to change this year if shortages continue. In the meantime, memory manufacturers are riding high demand and high prices to record profits. In revenue guidance released this week , Samsung Electronics predicts it will make between 19.9 and 20.1 trillion Korean won in operating profit (roughly $13.8 billion USD) in Q4 2025, compared to just 6.49 trillion won in Q4 of 2024. items.title: RFK Jr.â€™s dietary guidance: Food funnel features slab of red meat, butter
items.summary: Old-school food pyramid returns, but jumbled and upside-down, like a funnel.
items.body: Anti-vaccine Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Agriculture Secretary Brook Rollins unveiled the delayed 2025â€“2030 Dietary Guidelines for America Wednesday, which is already drawing criticism for its ties to the meat and dairy industry. Headlining with the advice to "eat real food," the new guidelines , which are updated every five years, are in a brisk, citation-free 10-page document. Overall, the new guidelines: lambaste added sugars and highly processed foods (though it doesn't clearly define them); ditch previous limits on alcohol while directing Americans to just drink "less"; beef up recommendations for protein, including red meat; and appear to embrace saturated fats while not actually changing the 2020â€“2025 recommendation for how much you should eatâ€”which was and continues to be no more than 10 percent of total daily calories. "We are ending the war on saturated fats," Kennedy said triumphantly in a White House press briefing Wednesday, despite the lack of a change. He went on to proclaim that "today, our government declares war on added sugar," though that too is questionable. Read full article Comments

items.title: These dogs eavesdrop on their owners to learn new words
items.summary: â€œUnder the right conditions, some dogs present behaviors strikingly similar to those of young children.â€
items.body: When it comes to cognitive ability, not all dogs are created equal. Most dogs can learn simple action cues like â€œsitâ€ or â€œdown." But so-called â€œgifted word learnerâ€ (GWL) dogs exhibit a remarkable ability to learn the names of objectsâ€”for example, learning the names of specific toys so well that they can retrieve them from a large pile of toys on command. And according to a new study published in the journal Science, they can even learn labels for new toys just by overhearing their owners talking about those toys. Per the authors, this suggests that GWL dogs have sociocognitive skills that are functionally comparable to those of 18-month-old human toddlers. Co-author Claudia Fugazza of EÃ¶tvÃ¶s LorÃ¡nd University in Budapest, Hungary, has been studying canine behavior and cognition for several years as part of the Genius Dog Challenge . For instance, the groupâ€™s 2022 study discovered that dogs store key sensory features about their toysâ€”notably what they look like and how they smellâ€”and recall those features when searching for the named toy. Prior studies had suggested that dogs typically rely on vision, or a combination of sight and smell, to locate target objects. GWL dogs can alsoâ€¦

items.title: Grok assumes users seeking images of underage girls have â€œgood intentâ€
items.summary: Expert explains how simple it could be to tweak Grok to block CSAM outputs.
items.body: For weeks, xAI has faced backlash over undressing and sexualizing images of women and children generated by Grok. One researcher conducted a 24-hour analysis of the Grok account on X and estimated that the chatbot generated over 6,000 images an hour flagged as "sexually suggestive or nudifying," Bloomberg reported . While the chatbot claimed that xAI supposedly "identified lapses in safeguards" that allowed outputs flagged as child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and was "urgently fixing them," Grok has proven to be an unreliable spokesperson , and xAI has not announced any fixes. A quick look at Grok's safety guidelines on its public GitHub shows they were last updated two months ago. The GitHub also indicates that, despite prohibiting such content, Grok maintains programming that could make it likely to generate CSAM. Read full article Comments

items.summary: Benjamin and Chance cover this week in Apple news, including the long-awaited announcement that the Apple Card will be switching from Goldman Sachs to Chase, in about . Also, Fitness+ doesnâ€™t quite live up to its own new year marketing hype, NBA live-streaming kicks off on Vision Pro, and Apple makâ€¦

items.title: Are people updating to iOS 26? Hereâ€™s what the data reportedly shows
items.summary: iOS 26 has been available for nearly four months, yet reporting from Statcounter indicates the iPhone update is lagging significantly behind predecessors in adoption, with most users opting to stay on iOS 18. Meanwhile, data from TelemetryDeck paints a different, more optimistic picture. moreâ€¦

items.title: You can get a four-pack of Samsung SmartTag 2 trackers for just $45
items.summary: Samsung SmartTag 2 trackers are back on sale if you're willing to pick up a bundle. Woot has a four-pack down to just $45, which undercuts the previous all-time low weâ€™ve seen on Amazon ($55) by $10. That's a discount of 55 percent from the retail price of $100. It's a compelling opportunity to stoâ€¦

items.title: The New York Times profiles Appleâ€™s expected next CEO
items.summary: It has long been an open secret that John Ternus is a leading candidate to succeed Tim Cook as Apple CEO, following more than fourteen years at the helm. Bloombergâ€™s Mark Gurman has reinforced that expectation through years of reporting on Appleâ€™s succession planning. Today, The New York Times addsâ€¦

items.title: Some quantum computers might need more power than supercomputers
items.summary: A preliminary analysis suggests that industrially useful quantum computers designs come with a broad spectrum of energy footprints, including some larger than the most powerful existing supercomputers

items.title: Apple shuts down AliveCor antitrust claims after earlier Apple Watch patent win
items.summary: AliveCorâ€™s latest attempt to revive its Apple Watch antitrust case fell short this week, with a federal appeals court handing Apple another win. Todayâ€™s development follows the companyâ€™s earlier win in the International Trade Commission patent case last spring. moreâ€¦

items.title: Deals: AirPods Pro 3 back at holiday lows, M5 iPad Pro $150 off, black/natural Milanese Loop, and more
items.summary: Joining the ongoing $100 price drops on Apple Watch Series 11, todayâ€™s 9to5Toys Lunch Break is headlined by AirPods Pro 3. Youâ€™ll now find Appleâ€™s latest and greatest in-ear listening experience sitting within $1 of the best Amazon price we have tracked to date, Black Friday and the holidays includâ€¦

items.title: Disney+ announces vertical video is coming to the app soon
items.summary: Disney+ will soon be home not just to the Disney, Hulu, and ESPN content librariesâ€”vertical video is being added too. Here are the details from Disneyâ€™s announcement. moreâ€¦

items.title: iPhone Fold might be more like an iPad than an iPhone
items.summary: The latest iPhone Fold leaks provoke interesting questions around whether the device will feel more like an iPhone or an iPad. moreâ€¦

items.title: City-sized iceberg has turned into a giant swimming pool
items.summary: Satellite photos show meltwater on the surface of iceberg A23a collecting in an unusual way, which may be a sign that the huge berg is about to break apart

items.title: ChatGPT Health is a marketplace, guess who is the product?
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Apple TV unveils the return of one of its best-reviewed shows
items.summary: Apple TV has a stacked lineup of returning shows coming soon, including the just-unveiled season 2 of Drops of God, one of the streamerâ€™s best reviewed shows ever. moreâ€¦

items.title: The Smartlet dual watch band is the most ridiculous Apple Watch accessory yet
items.summary: Choosing between a conventional watch and an Apple Watch can be tricky, especially if you love mechanical watches but still want the features of its high-tech offspring. But the creators of what may be the most ridiculous Apple Watch accessory yet think you shouldnâ€™t have to choose â€¦ moreâ€¦

items.title: Red tattoo ink causes man to lose all his hair and stop sweating
items.summary: A manâ€™s severe reaction to a tattoo, which made all his hair fall out and destroyed his sweat glands, has reignited concerns about the immune effects of some tattoo inks

items.title: Apple Watch blood sugar monitoring a step closer as new tech launches
items.summary: Apple Watch blood sugar monitoring is something the company reportedly wanted to do right from the start. A report back in 2023 said that the very first Apple Watch was initially intended to launch with non-invasive glucose measurement as a headline feature. There have been numerous reports since tâ€¦

items.title: Apple Back to School deals are live in several countries
items.summary: Appleâ€™s Back to School deals in the US and Europe donâ€™t launch until the summer, but they are live in several countries that get them much earlier in the year. In addition to the normal education discounts, you can choose from one of a number of free accessories when buying an iPad, MacBook, or iMaâ€¦

items.title: Our verdict on The Player of Games: Iain M. Banks is still a master
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club has just finished our December read, Iain M. Banks's sci-fi novel The Player of Games - and most of us were fans of this big-thinking Culture tale

items.title: The challenges of writing from the perspective of a sex robot

items.title: Read an extract from Annie Bot by Sierra Greer
items.summary: In this extract from the award-winning science fiction novel Annie Bot, the January read for the New Scientist Book Club, we are introduced to Sierra Greer's protagonist, a sex robot called Annie

items.title: Rare Saturn-sized rogue planet is first to have its mass measured
items.summary: Researchers have confirmed the mass of a free-floating planet thanks to a lucky convergence of ground- and space-based telescopes

items.title: Chess can be made fairer by rearranging the pieces
items.summary: Chess960 involves shuffling the pieces at the back of the board, and an analysis suggests doing so can increase the complexity of the game to favour white, black or neither player

items.title: The 3 things you should do this New Year to foster a positive mindset
items.summary: Olivia Remes, a mental health researcher at the University of Cambridge, says these are the three things everyone should do this New Year to cultivate a more positive mindset

items.title: Jennifer Lawrence stars in this high-stakes dystopian film
items.summary: The 12 districts of Panem must offer up two tributes to fight in the annual Hunger Games

items.title: Could 2026 be the year we start using quantum computers for chemistry?
items.summary: Understanding the chemical properties of a molecule is an inherently quantum problem, making quantum computers a good tool for the job â€“ and we may start seeing this take off in 2026

items.title: Three supermassive black holes have been spotted merging into one
items.summary: Astronomers have found a system of three supermassive black holes, all actively feeding, that appear to be combining into a single system â€“ a rare event that will help elucidate the physics of complex mergers

items.title: The duo kite-skiing 4000 kilometres across Antarctica for science
items.summary: An explorer and a glaciologist are kite-skiing across Antarctica with a ground-penetrating radar to gather data that will help understand the past and future of the ice sheet

items.title: Star that seemed to vanish more than 130 years ago is found again
items.summary: In 1892, astronomer Edward Emerson Barnard thought he saw a bright star near Venus, but then it vanished. We may now know why

items.title: Controversial satellites launching in 2026 will reflect light to Earth
items.summary: Reflect Orbital plans to launch thousands of reflective mirrors to produce "sunlight on demand", but researchers are sceptical about whether the reflected light will be enough to generate electricity

items.title: BepiColombo mission will start to unpick Mercury's secrets in 2026
items.summary: The BepiColombo mission has been on its way to Mercury since 2018 and will finally start orbiting the planet and taking X-ray images in the second half of 2026

items.title: World's first subsea desalination facility will start running in 2026
items.summary: Flocean, a Norwegian company, is set to open the worldâ€™s first commercial-scale subsea desalination plant, an approach that could cut the cost and energy used to make seawater drinkable

items.title: 2026 Mars mission will set out to solve the mystery of its moons
items.summary: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency will be launching the Martian Moons eXploration mission next year, which should finally tell us how Mars acquired the moons Phobos and Deimos

items.title: Why stroking seedlings can help them grow big and strong
items.summary: The science behind why stroking your seedlings actually works. If youâ€™re worried about your seedlings getting long and leggy, try a bit of home thigmomorphogenesis, advises James Wong

items.title: Why I'm going to reap the mental health benefits of stargazing in 2026
items.summary: Navigating the night sky can have a positive effect on our well-being. This will be the year I learn the constellations, resolves Michael Brooks

items.title: The best new science fiction books of 2026
items.summary: On the horizon for this year are Ann Leckie's latest, Neil Jordan's debut and more from Adrian Tchaikovsky. Exciting times, says our sci-fi columnist Emily H. Wilson

items.title: The best new popular science books of 2026
items.summary: Clear out your shelves for a bumper new crop of books by authors including Naomi Klein, Rebecca Solnit and Xand Van Tulleken, says culture editor Alison Flood

items.title: Could James and the Giant Peach inspire the future of food?
items.summary: In the latest in our imagined history of inventions yet to come, Future Chronicles columnist Rowan Hooper reveals how by the 2030s, botanists had worked out how to grow hybridised superplants to help feed the world

items.title: Physicists stirred up controversy with scientific cooking tips in 2025
items.summary: Cacio e pepe pasta and boiled eggs were the subjects of meticulous studies aiming to help cooks achieve perfection, but the reimagined recipes weren't always well-received

items.title: The emotion you never knew you had, and how to feel more of it
items.summary: The warm and fuzzy emotion of kama muta underlies vital feel-good experiences like social connection and feeling part of something bigger. But are you getting enough of it?

items.title: The century-long hunt for the gigantic meteorite that vanished
items.summary: A soldier returned from the Sahara desert in 1916 with a wild story about a meteorite that dwarfed all others. Over 100 years of hunting yielded nothing â€“ but now twin brothers think they have solved the puzzle

items.title: The cassette tape made a comeback in 2025 thanks to a DNA upgrade
items.summary: With a storage capacity of 36 petabytes, a DNA-based cassette tape can hold every song every recorded, and it could be on the market within five years

items.title: EU carbon border tax will force others to cut emissions from 2026
items.summary: In 2026, the European Union will start charging a carbon-emissions-based tax on imported goods such as steel, cement and fertilisers â€“ and countries including the UK are likely to follow

items.title: We'll learn about LSD's potential for treating anxiety in 2026
items.summary: Two later-stage trials investigating LSD for treating anxiety are due to conclude in 2026, which could lead to the drug being approved for the common mental health condition

items.title: A controversial experiment threatened to kill the multiverse in 2025
items.summary: A photon was apparently detected in two places at once in a twist on the classic double-slit experiment, but many physicists didn't accept the results

items.title: Benefits of mRNA cancer vaccines could exceed $75 billion in US alone
items.summary: An analysis of ongoing trials suggests that mRNA cancer vaccines have the potential to deliver health benefits worth $75 billion each year in the US alone

items.title: Mathematicians unified key laws of physics in 2025

items.title: Low on energy? A new understanding of rest could help revitalise you
items.summary: There is a state of relaxation that few of us spend much time in, but which comes with profound well-being benefits. With healthier ageing, reduced risk of disease and feeling more energised all on offer, here's how to get there

items.title: The best and most ridiculous robots of 2025 in pictures
items.summary: Some of the world's most advanced robots showed off their skills at tech shows and sporting events, doing everything from cooking shrimp to running half marathons

items.title: Inside world's ultimate X-ray machine before it becomes more powerful
items.summary: The Linac Coherent Light Source in California has been firing record-breaking X-ray pulses for years, but now itâ€™s due for a shutdown and an upgrade. When it is turned back on, it will be even more powerful

items.title: Microsoft made a splash with a controversial quantum computer in 2025
items.summary: The Majorana 1 quantum computer was hailed as a significant breakthrough by Microsoft, but critics say the company has yet to prove it actually works despite a year of debate

items.title: Human-plant hybrid cells reveal truth about dark DNA in our genome
items.summary: It has been claimed that because most of our DNA is active, it must be important, but now human-plant hybrid cells have been used to show this activity is mostly random noise

items.title: Gene-edited babies are the future â€“ but these CRISPR start-ups arenâ€™t
items.summary: Three start-ups are aiming to create gene-edited babies. Columnist Michael Le Page has no doubt that editing our offspring will one day become routine, but not like this

items.title: Mathematicians spent 2025 exploring the edge of mathematics

items.title: Was 2025 the year we found signs of past life on Mars?

items.title: 'Spectacular' progress has been made towards useful quantum computers
items.summary: At the Q2B Silicon Valley conference, scientific and business leaders of the quantum computing industry hailed "spectacular" progress being made towards practical devices â€“ but said that challenges remain

items.title: A ghostly glow was seen emanating from living things in 2025
items.summary: The detection of mercurial particles of light emanating from mice led to a flurry of interest in biophotons, a mysterious phenomenon that could have applications in agriculture

items.title: 6 incredible new dinosaurs we discovered in 2025
items.summary: Palaeontologists reported some remarkable dinosaur fossils this year, including a Velociraptor relative, a dome-headed pachycephalosaur and one of the most heavily armoured creatures that ever lived

items.title: The worldâ€™s first fully 3D-printed microscope went big in 2025
items.summary: A microscope that cost less than Â£50 and took under 3 hours to build using a common 3D printer could be transformative for students and researchers with limited funding

items.title: New Year's resolutions work better if you know what to measure
items.summary: From our immune systems to our microbiomes, if you're planning to make health improvements in the new year, having an eye on the numbers can help set you up for success

items.title: Why we all need a little festive pedantry when it comes to snowflakes

items.summary: The ideas presented in George Lakoff and Srini Narayanan's The Neural Mind are fascinating, but the writing is far less compelling

items.title: How not to misread science fiction
items.summary: Focusing on the futuristic tech that appears in sci-fi without paying attention to the actual point of the story is a big mistake, says Annalee Newitz

items.title: Why it is important to make space for solitude over the festive season
items.summary: The festive season is a period of social connection for many of us, but alone time can be equally enriching, says Thuy-vy Nguyen, principal investigator of the Solitude Lab

items.title: Bill Bryson on why he has updated A Short History of Nearly Everything

items.title: You can upgrade your immune system, but not in the way you think
items.summary: From vitamin C to your microbiome and mindset, the latest science of immunity is often counterintuitive. Here's how to give your system a fighting chance to overcome infection

items.title: Booze, beach, beaten - how England lost the Ashes

items.title: The man behind the headlines - Salah, by Klopp, Diaz and more
items.summary: BBC Sport explores Mohamed Salah's personality with help from the people who know him best.

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: Are we living in a simulation? This experiment could tell us

items.summary: BBC Sport hears from inside the England setup about how artificial intelligence is powering plans for next summer's World Cup.

items.title: Watch trailer for Robbie Savage: Managing Macclesfield FC

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life

items.title: 'Raise hell' - the fastest bowler you might not have heard of
items.summary: The story of Duncan Spencer, the "frighteningly fast" bowler who could have played for England or Australia.

items.title: A new understanding of causality could fix quantum theoryâ€™s fatal flaw
items.summary: Quantum theory fails to explain how the reality we experience emerges from the world of particles. A new take on quantum cause and effect could bridge the gap
